Posted By: Mylon (1/17/2010 11:59:28 AM)
Rating:

posts.post_content: Stupidly, ridiculously good spell, especially for common, and if you can get off multiples in the first few turns then it'll probably be game. It's [Lava Spike](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Lava Spike) glued to [Mind Rot](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Mind Rot), and that 2-for-1 convenience somehow equates to costing one mana LESS. This is the lovely little lady that makes Jund the force it is, and a [Bloodbraid Elf](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Bloodbraid Elf) towing one of these along is probably the best use of 2RG that has ever been. Really great card, just all-around awesome, and not playing it in a B/R deck these days is all but inexcusable. Go get yourself a playset; it's common and cheap. 5/5

Posted By: SereneChaos (7/6/2010 11:39:19 PM)
Rating:

posts.post_content:
@Caldlow: Blighting has two separate effects:
  
"Blightning deals 3 damage to target player."
  
"Target player discards two cards."
  
   
Preventing one does not prevent the other. Though, according to the syntax of the card, if you cannot target a player with the first ability, the second ability has no target.
  
   
Also, the damage blightning deals cannot be prevented until it resolves on a legal target. This means that the effects of the card have already resolved by the time the damage is prevented. Safe P\*\*\*age doesn't actually "prevent" any of this card's effects. It only responds to the damage blightning deals after the spell resolves.
posts.html:
@Caldlow: Blighting has two separate effects:
"Blightning deals 3 damage to target player."
"Target player discards two cards."

Preventing one does not prevent the other. Though, according to the syntax of the card, if you cannot target a player with the first ability, the second ability has no target.

Also, the damage blightning deals cannot be prevented until it resolves on a legal target. This means that the effects of the card have already resolved by the time the damage is prevented. Safe P***age doesn't actually "prevent" any of this card's effects. It only responds to the damage blightning deals after the spell resolves.

Posted By: Kelrath (7/1/2010 10:25:57 AM)

posts.post_content: I'm conflicted about this card. On the one hand it seems extremely annoying and overpowered, and when you play against Jund, there is very little you can do to win if the opponent happens to draw two of them over the course of the game. On the other hand, if you look at the card itself, it has the same CMC and discard effect as [Mind Rot](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Mind Rot) (which no one considers overpowered), and gets a bonus 3 damage to the player (which isn't really that big a deal in most games) in exchange for being multicolored. Normally this would make it balanced, however: 1) multicolored stopped being a drawback when they started exclusively focusing entire sets on it and printing tons of dual lands, 2) Three damage is a bit too much - two would probably have been more fair, and 3) Cascade from Bloodbraid Elf is actually the biggest thing that makes this card broken. So in conclusion, it's not so much the card itself as it is the Alara standard environment. Fortunately, it's going to rotate o... [(see all)](javascript:void(0);)
posts.html:

posts.post_content:
The power of Jund:  
[Bituminous blast](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Bituminous blast) into [bloodbraid elf](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=bloodbraid elf) into [blightning](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=blightning), swing with [bloodbraid elf](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=bloodbraid elf).  
10 damage and discard two cards, good sir.  
and on turn 5, that usually wins.  
That's why they call a double cascade "living the dream." :)
